Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with simple representation of winged lion (or less likely sphinx) walking to right, and neb-basket sign below; motif stamped rather than incised, encircled by groove near edge; pierced through diameter; glaze bright yellow all over; no core visible.
Curator's comments: The faience object was analysed by proton induced X-ray emission spectrometry (PIXE) under a 3 MeV energy proton beam for characterisation of the elemental chemical composition (major, minor and trace elements), in March 2014, by the Centre de Recherche et de Restauration des Musées de France (C2RMF). Scarabs and scaraboids decorated with a winged lion or sphinx on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 20-31, see especially no. 25 for this piece; Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 16 and 62) and according to his annotations on pl. XXXVII, no. 25, there were two examples of this specimen, in yellow paste and from the Factory (marked 'F' on the drawing). This type of scaraboid was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII A, subtype A191-193). Gordon misidentified the scaraboid AN1896-1908-EA.914 kept in the Ashmolean Museum with Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 25. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 25)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.013) (phase 3)
